title.narrative: Ferghana Valley Water Resources Management Project

description.narrative: The objectives of the Ferghana Valley Water Resources Management Project are: to improve the capacity for increased productivity of irrigated agriculture in the Ferghana valley by improving land and water management, and to improve safety and regulation of the Kayrakum dam and reservoir, thereby contributing to enhanced water management security and efficiency at the basin level. The original closing date was May 31, 2011, which was extended to May 31, 2013 when the additional financing was approved. It is to extend the closing date by an additional year to May 31, 2014. The extension is necessary to complete all works and strengthen the Water User Associations (WUAs). Construction works can only be implemented during a few months per year. As a result of this, some of the works have been delayed. It would be challenging to recover these delays as only a few months of effective construction time remain before the closing date, by which time it is unlikely that all works will be completed. This will be the second closing date extension for the project for a cumulative extension of three years.

title.narrative: Collection of billed water fees by WUAs

comment.narrative: Baseline value is shown as for the date of AF approval.

Water fee collection rates in 9 months of 2013: WUA “Mirzomalik” – 80.6%; WUA “Kavsari Kandi Kuhan” – 80.7%, WUA “Dehqon” – 91.6%.As cotton harvesting period is continuing collection of water fees is ongoing.Collection of water service feesis ongoing and finalfigures for year 2012 will be reported to the Bank through the Implementation progress report in January 2013.

title.narrative: Detailed dam geotechnical study completed and an executive summary with all the main recommendations prepared to be shared regionally

comment.narrative: THIS IS A NEW INDICATOR THAT WAS INTRODUCED UNDER THE AF & 1-ST ORDER RESTRUCTURING APPROVED ON JUNE 23, 2010

The PMU did not succeed in identifying the company which might be interested in the bidding. Based on the information provided bythe PMU, and after a visit to the Kayrakkum dam site, the Bank agreed to the alternative option offered by the PMU to protect theupstream face of the dam instead of the downstream face.

title.narrative: Area returned to effective irrigation under the project.

The indicator has been exceeded due to impact of rehabilitated tubewells and pumping stations. However, recommendations were madeto verify this figure through application of pondage method based calculations.

title.narrative: Water users provided with new/improved irrigation and drainage services (number)

comment.narrative: The indicator has been added as per the corporate requirement to include core indicator into results frameworks before December2012.
Results will include dehkan farms, household plots and other groups of water users. Results for the indicator will be reported tothe Bank through the Impact Evaluation Survey.
Results will include dehkan farms, household plots and other groups of water users. Results for the indicator will be reported tothe Bank through the Impact Evaluation Survey.

The indicator has been introduced in line with the corporate requirement for including core sector indicators in the ISRs, resultsfor the indicator will be reported during the next Bank's implementation support mission.

The indicator has been discussed with the PMU and number of direct beneficiaries will be calculated as a number of water usersbenefited from improved access to irrigation as a result of project interventions (rehabilitation of I&D, VDW and Institutionalsupport to WUAs). Final results will be reported through the impact assessment survey and the Borrower's ICR.

title.narrative: Forecast accuracy for available reservoir storage volumes and inflow/outflow volumes improved

comment.narrative: Forecasts are currently provided by the Scientific-Information Center of the Water Commission; the data can be also found onwww.cawater-info.net. Data is updated quarterly. The mission had discussed current status of the existing hydroposts on the upperside of Kayrakkum reservoir – Okchar Hydropost and lower side of reservoir – Kizilkishlak Hydropost with the Head of the SUEHydrometeorology service, Mr. Mahmad Safarov. Mr. Safarov confirmed that both hydroposts were rehabilitated in 1993 and 2003respectively. Currently information on the both posts is collected and reported manually. Being international hydroposts ontransboundary rivers information from these hydroposts is reported twice a day to the regional center.
